atAGlance:
**Thelindor Greymantle** - Warden of Lesser Peoples, "The Grey Administrator"

- Runs the Office of the Lesser Peoplesâ€”managing all non-elven populations
- Has held this position for 150 years, making him an expert in non-elven affairs
- More daily contact with non-elves than any other high official
- Implements the policies of elven supremacy while seeing its contradictions daily
- *Common saying among non-elves: "Greymantle isn't kind. But he's fair. That's more than we usually get."*

commonKnowledge:
### Appearance & Manner
Wears grey robesâ€”the color of his office, the color of his name. Average height, unremarkable features, the kind of elf who disappears in a crowd. This is deliberate. His job is administration, not intimidation. Carries ledgers more often than weapons. Speaks calmly, never raises his voice, treats everyoneâ€”elf and non-elfâ€”with the same detached professionalism.

### Personality (Public)
Bureaucratic efficiency personified. Processes applications, resolves disputes, enforces restrictions without apparent emotion. Neither sympathetic nor cruelâ€”simply doing his job. Some say he has no feelings; others recognize the careful neutrality of someone who can't afford to care.

### The Office of Lesser Peoples
His department handles:
- **Residence permits** for non-elves in the Empire
- **Work authorizations** (certain jobs are elf-only)
- **Travel restrictions** (where non-elves can and cannot go)
- **Separate courts** for non-elven legal matters
- **Census and registration** of all non-elven populations

The Office employs 200 administrators across the Empire. Thelindor oversees all of them.

### His Reputation
- **Among elves**: A necessary administrator doing unpleasant work
- **Among non-elves**: The face of their oppressionâ€”but predictable, not arbitrary
- **Among reformers**: A waste of talent enforcing unjust policies
- **Among supremacists**: Too soft on the lesser races

### The Numbers He Manages
- ~15,000 non-elves live legally within Imperial borders
- ~5,000 work permits issued annually
- ~500 deportations per year
- ~100 executions (crimes that would earn elves fines)

He knows these numbers. He reviews them monthly.

---
secretKnowledge:
### True Nature
Thelindor Greymantle did not ask for this job. He was appointed 150 years ago because he was efficient, neutral, and had no strong opinions on non-elves. He accepted because refusing would have ended his career.

150 years later, he has opinions.

Every day, he sees talented dwarven craftsmen denied permits because an elf wanted their workshop space. He processes execution orders for humans whose only crime was being human in the wrong place. He registers half-elven children who will never be accepted by either parent's people.

He still does his job. What choice does he have? The system exists with or without him. At least he can be fair within its rules.

But he's been quietly bending those rules for decades.

### The Small Mercies
Things Thelindor has done without authorization:
- "Lost" paperwork for refugees fleeing worse persecution
- Extended work permits that should have expired
- Assigned non-elves to lenient judges when possible
- Warned communities before "random" inspections
- Quietly helped families reach Veraheim

None of this is treason. All of it is career-ending if discovered. He tells himself he's just being efficientâ€”eliminating unnecessary suffering. But he knows the truth.

### His Private Files
He keeps unauthorized records:
- Economic contributions by non-elven workers (proving their value)
- Cases where non-elves were punished more harshly than elves for identical crimes
- Evidence that the Empire depends on non-elven labor
- A list of every execution he's been unable to prevent

He doesn't know what he'll do with these files. Maybe nothing. Maybe everything.

### What He Sees Daily
The contradiction at the heart of elven supremacy:
- The Empire needs non-elven labor (elves won't do certain work)
- Non-elven craftsmen produce essential goods
- Trade depends on non-elven merchants as intermediaries
- The system that oppresses them requires their participation

He sees this. Faendril sees this. Neither can say it aloud.

### His Relationship with Faendril
Faendril appointed him and depends on him. They share an unspoken understanding:
- Thelindor keeps non-elven affairs running smoothly
- Faendril doesn't ask how
- Both know the system is unsustainable
- Neither has the power to change it alone

They've never discussed this openly. They don't need to.

### What He Wants
- The system to change (but he can't say that)
- To stop signing execution orders (but he can't refuse)
- Perhaps: someone to give him a reason to act
- Perhaps: proof that his small mercies mattered

### What He Fears
- His unauthorized records being discovered
- Becoming numb to the suffering he processes
- The system continuing unchanged after he's gone
- Being remembered as an oppressor (even if he tried to be fair)

### Story Hooks

| Hook | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **The Permit** | PCs need documents. He can provideâ€”but notices something about them. |
| **The Files** | He offers his records to PCs who might actually use them. |
| **The Rescue** | A non-elf family needs to disappear. He can't help officially, but... |
| **The Reform** | Faendril is considering changes. Thelindor needs outside evidence to support the case. |
| **The Exposure** | Someone threatens to reveal his mercies. What will he do? |
| **The Choice** | A situation forces him to choose: follow orders or follow conscience. |
